awd_titl_txt: Establishing a High Resolution Framework for Age Determination
awd_abstract_narration:
Anchoring events in accurate chronological timeframes is of the utmost importance in answering questions about the past. Scientific developments in the field of radiocarbon dating have led to what is being called the "third radiocarbon revolution." These new methods permit archaeologists to construct more detailed and accurate chronologies than have previously been possible, often at the decadal scale or less. These more accurate chronologies, in turn, allow researchers to better understand the pace and timing of key cultural developments and turning points in prehistoric societies. These developments have been pivotal in revising understandings of European archaeology, but similar applications to large-scale chronology-building have lagged behind in North America. In this project, Dr. Jennifer Birch (University of Georgia) and Dr. Sturt Manning (Cornell University) will construct for the first time a high-precision radiocarbon (14C) chronology for select Northern Iroquoian site relocation sequences in Ontario and New York State. The methods employed include (a) Accelerator Mass Spectrometry (AMS) dating of short-lived organic material from select proveniences at 42 Iroquoian village sites and (b) sophisticated Bayesian Chronological Modeling of those dates - integrating archaeological, historical and radiocarbon information. The project will provide training for graduate students, including workshops on chronological modelling and Iroquoian archaeology at the University of Georgia and Cornell.

The significance of this project represents nothing less than the potential redefinition of the Northern Iroquoian archaeological chronology. A pilot study by Birch and Manning suggested that in one part of Northern Iroquoia, the existing ceramic chronology misplaced sites in time by as many as 50-100 years. This work focusses on the centuries which preceded and followed the first instances of direct European contact in the Northeast and has significant implications for the study of the timing and effects of pre- and post-contact cultural transformations. Understanding how the lived experiences of individuals and communities articulate with the broad sweep of history is a key theoretical interest in archaeology. The refined, independent chronology produced by this project will permit enhanced understanding of the development of Iroquoian nations and confederacies, the timing and directionality of conflict, and the introduction of European trade goods, as well as the interplay between these key societal transformations.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Placing archaeological phenomena into accurate timeframes is essential to understanding sequences of events that took place in the human past prior to a secure documentary history. What has come to be known as the “Dating Iroquoia” project constructed a high-precision radiocarbon (14C) chronology for five Northern Iroquoian community sequences in Ontario (ON) and New York State (NY). The refined independent chronology was produced integrating archaeology, documentary history, and 14C data through the application of Bayesian Chronological Modelling. Methodologically, the project resulted in several innovations in strategies for overcoming plateaus and reversals in the radiocarbon calibration curve in absence of stratigraphic sequences, including the use of the in-built age in wood charcoal as an informative terminus post quem.

The project’s results have enhanced and revolutionized understandings of the historical development of Iroquoian Nations and confederacies. This included reframing narratives around the timing and directionality of conflict, the introduction of European-manufactured goods, and associated implications for the formation of the Huron-Wendat and Haudenosaunee confederacies. The implications of this work have caused a major re-think of events surrounding the early contact era in ways that highlight Indigenous agency and differential responses to internal and external societal inputs during a period of widespread cultural change. These findings also have global implications for the historicization of archaeological phenomena and theory-building related to processes of coalescence, conflict, and politigenesis in non-state societies.

The “Dating Iroquoia” project was conducted in consultation with the Huron-Wendat Nation and has inspired future research agendas based on collaborative Indigenous archaeology. The project facilitated the training of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. Results of the project were communicated with the public, Indigenous, cultural resource management, and academic communities through blog posts, animated videos, a special section of the newsletter of the Society for American Archaeology, and in an article in The Conversation, as well as publications in top-tier journals including Science Advances, Radiocarbon, and American Antiquity. Reception from the archaeological community has been positive and has inspired similar efforts to construct high-precision radiocarbon timelines in other world regions.

 


Last Modified: 10/31/2022
Modified by: Jennifer Birch
